title: Levi Strauss Looks Beyond Jeans With IPO
summary: Denim pioneer is seeking to raise more than $600 million to make acquisitions. Levi Strauss & Co., which invented bluejeans and dominated the category for more than a century, is looking to go beyond denim.

title: European Union Agrees to New Copyright Law
summary: Tech platforms would be liable for violations, while news publishers would be able to negotiate licenses with Google and others. BRUSSELS-The European Union agreed on a new copyright law aimed at reining in tech giants and throwing a lifeline to news publishers.

title: Death of a California Dream
summary: Gavin Newsom gives up on Jerry Brown's bullet-train fiasco.. Like Richard Nixon and the Vietnam War, California Gov. Gavin Newsom inherited a quagmire in the state's bullet train with no good options. Rather than attempt a full-out retreat, the Governor announced Tuesday that he would cut taxpayer losses by completing a segment in the sparsely populated San Joaquin Valley. But please don't call it a train to nowhere.

title: Bankrupt Freight Hauler NEMF Wins Approval to Tap Cash
summary: Banks say NEMF owner should finance bankruptcy. New England Motor Freight Inc. settled a court fight with banks worried they would be left unpaid in the trucking company's bankruptcy, while longtime Chairman Myron P. Shevell still owes the company millions.

title: Brexiteers for Argentina
summary: If devalue-and-inflate is Britain's best post-EU plan, Brexit is doomed.. Leaving the European Union will leave the United Kingdom better off only if the country makes itself more competitive by reducing taxes, trade barriers and regulatory burdens. But recent comments from leading Brexiteers show London's anti-EU faction is thinking a lot smaller.

title: Discriminating Against Oracle
summary: Why hasn't Trump's Labor secretary killed an Obama-era lawsuit?. Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta has tried to ease regulation, but unfair enforcement is another story. Witness Labor's continuing stickup of Oracle over diversity in hiring based on dubious evidence.

title: Maybe It'll Be Beto
summary: The Democrats are going to lose if their nominee can't hold a stage with Trump.. How many other people watched the entire 80 or 85 minutes of President Trump's rally in El Paso, Texas, Monday night on Fox? The pre-rally expectation was that this event would be an effort to build support for the border wall. Instead, it obviously was a test-run of issues for the 2020 campaign, covering everything from A to Zzz.

title: Make Trump Popular Again
summary: While he strikes a tone of unity, his opponents seek ideological purity.. President Trump's standing has improved over the past week, and credit his State of the Union address. Say what you will about the ricocheting, all-over-the-place speech, but as Mr. Trump drove to Capitol Hill to deliver it, his average favorable rating from RealClearPolitics was 40.8%, with 55.5% unfavorable-his worst since early September. As of Wednesday, Mr. Trump's favorables had risen to 43.3% and his unfavorables had declined to 53.4%.

title: Vaping Is Harm Reduction
summary: The surgeon general is right on opioids, but wrong on tobacco.. 'A lot of people still think e-cigarettes are not harmful," U.S. Surgeon General Jerome Adams said last week. "But studies show that nicotine is, pound for pound, as addictive as heroin." Dr. Adams, speaking to the Community Anti-Drug Coalitions of America, was making an appeal to fear, not science. Drug consumption is measured by the dosage, not the pound.

title: 'Good Reasons for Bad Feelings' Review: Suffering's Silver Lining
summary: What are the evolutionary reasons explaining why the human species is so vulnerable to disease-mental as well as physical?. For some time I've been predicting that the academic field of evolutionary psychology, which studies how natural selection has influenced the working of the human mind, will eventually go extinct: Eventually, all psychology will be understood as a result of evolution. Randolph Nesse, director of the Center for Evolution and Medicine at Arizona State University, is a leader of what might be called "evolutionary psychiatry"-a medical discipline that hardly exists at present, but which promises in particular to help us understand individual behavioral pathologies.

title: Why China's New Year Wasn't Very Festive
summary: As the country tries to become a consumer economy, Xi robs the biggest spenders.. The Lunar New Year is China's annual festive high point, but the arrival of the Year of the Pig was noticeably subdued. For the latter half of 2018, real growth in consumer spending per capita declined, particularly among well-heeled urban Chinese, endangering the shift to a consumer driven economy on which the country's future depends.

title: Janus Barely Dents Public-Sector Union Membership
summary: Blue-state officials make legal moves to shore up an important source of political support.. Whatever happened to public-sector unions? Justice Elena Kagan warned of "large scale consequences . . . involving millions of employees" in her dissent last year from the Supreme Court's ruling in Janus v. Afscme. Yet according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, unions in state and local government only lost 54,000 members, falling from 6.244 million to 6.19 million in 2018-a decline of less than 1%.

title: How to Reduce Prescription-Drug Prices: First, Do No Harm
summary: Top-down controls restrict access. Instead, encourage patients to shop around among pharmacies.. Everyone wants to reduce prescription drug prices, but how? First, do no harm. It's true that Americans pay more for medication than just about anyone else: A 2018 report from the White House's Council of Economic Advisers found that, as of 2009, the price per dose of patented drugs was five times as high in the U.S. as in foreign markets.

title: SurveyMonkey CFO Announces Pending Departure from Company
summary: Tim Maly has served as CFO and COO of company since 2009. SVMK Inc., the parent company of online-questionnaire provider SurveyMonkey, said Timothy Maly, who has overseen the company's finances and operations for a decade, has decided to leave.

title: Republicans Look to Speed Up Confirmation of Nominees
summary: Senate rule change would limit power of minority party, angering Democrats. WASHINGTON-Senate Republicans are moving to accelerate the process for confirming many judicial and executive nominees, setting up another showdown with Democrats over the influence of the minority party in the chamber's procedures.

title: Cisco Evades Trade Fallout as Revenue, Profit Rise
summary: Company swings to a profit and beats analysts' expectations. Cisco Systems Inc. dodged significant fallout from the trade fight between the U.S. and China, posting strong growth in sales of its networking gear even as it raised prices to deal with the spat.

title: Driverless Car Data Shows Robots Still Need Humans
summary: California records show safety operators in GM and Waymo test vehicles are taking the wheel less. As General Motors Co. , Waymo and other companies race to develop fully driverless vehicles, new California state records show these companies are making progress but are still relying on human safety operators to take control of the wheel at times.

title: Dollar Bounces Back After One-Day Decline
summary: Strength of U.S. economy seen pushing the currency higher in recent days. The dollar ticked higher Wednesday, resuming its recent climb after slipping a day earlier for the first time in eight sessions.

title: Venezuela's Maduro Shows No Sign of Leaving. Now What?
summary: Weeks after opposition claims presidency with U.S. backing, leftist leader's military support holds firm. CARACAS, Venezuela-Many among Venezuela's opposition and its U.S. backers figured President Nicolás Maduro's regime would crumble quickly after Washington threw its support behind a plan designed to sap his military support and spur his exit. It hasn't happened that way.

title: Former Apple Lawyer Charged With Insider Trading
summary: Gene Daniel Levoff, who was fired from his position as a corporate lawyer for the iPhone maker, faces criminal charges and a civil suit from the SEC. The former Apple Inc. executive who enforced the company's insider-trading policies was charged with criminally violating those rules by allegedly dumping over $10 million in stock before the company in 2015 announced it fell short of iPhone sales expectations.

title: How a Nasdaq Loophole Fueled One Stock's Rise of 3,750%
summary: The stock exchange is set to make changes after software company Phunware's shares soar. A loophole in Nasdaq Inc.'s rules is under scrutiny after a roller-coaster ride in the stock of one small company highlighted how firms can go public without ample shares to trade.

title: U.S.-China Trade Optimism Drives Stocks Higher
summary: Fears about another partial government shutdown slowing U.S. economic activity have cooled. U.S. stocks edged higher, supported by optimism about U.S.-China trade negotiations and reports that President Trump is likely to sign a border-security deal that would keep the government open past Friday.

title: 'Nature's Nation: American Art and Environment' Review: History Through an Ideological Filter
summary: An overview of American art politicizes the past, offering demolition over deconstruction.. Salem, Mass.

title: Johnson & Johnson Talc Supplier Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Imerys Talc America spent millions of dollars defending itself against lawsuits alleging its talcum powder causes ovarian cancer and mesothelioma. Imerys Talc America Inc. has filed for bankruptcy protection as it faces accusations that the talc it supplied for Johnson & Johnson 's baby powder causes cancer.

title: Iran Rift Hurts U.S. Effort to Build Consensus on Mideast Policy
summary: European allies continue to balk at Trump administration's hard line on Tehran, casting a shadow over a security conference in Poland. WARSAW-Divisions over Iran are hindering the Trump administration's efforts to build consensus with NATO allies on Middle East policy, with European powers balking at joining top U.S. officials in Poland's capital for an event on regional security.

title: Afternoon Rallies Propel 2019 Stock Rebound
summary: Major indexes have climbed in the final hour of trading several times in recent sessions. Stocks are rallying in the final hour of trading more often than normal, a bullish development for market watchers bruised by recent volatility.

title: AIG Narrows Losses in Fourth Quarter
summary: Insurer reports net loss of $622 million after investment income fell nearly 20%. American International Group Inc.'s fourth-quarter loss narrowed as the insurance conglomerate benefited from the absence of a year-earlier tax adjustment, the company said in reporting its latest financial results Wednesday.

title: House Votes to Withdraw U.S. From War in Yemen
summary: Move sends message that lawmakers have little appetite for wars started without their approval, say proponents; still to come are contentious Senate vote, possibility of Trump veto. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives passed a war-powers resolution directing the removal of U.S. armed forces involved in the conflict in Yemen, putting pressure on the GOP-controlled Senate and raising the specter of a veto by President Trump.

title: Where Did All the Patrons Go?
summary: Fewer moneyed young people are donating to the arts than in previous generations, and that poses a major threat to cultural institutions..

title: As Brexit Deadline Nears, EU Loses Confidence in May
summary: Brussels wonders whether U.K. prime minister can deliver any Brexit deal. BRUSSELS-As the clock ticks down on the U.K.'s planned departure from the European Union, EU leaders are still waiting for a signal from British Prime Minister Theresa May on the next steps in negotiating a critical divorce deal.

title: Nighttime, Weekend Commuters Will Still Be Affected by L Train Plan
summary: MTA will reduce frequency of L train during weeknights and weekends beginning in April. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will start reducing the frequency of L train service between Manhattan and Brooklyn at 8 p.m. each weeknight beginning in April, so that it can repair a subway tunnel under the East River, officials announced Wednesday.

title: Treasury Yields Rise on Renewed Trade Hopes
summary: Yields climb for a third consecutive session. Prices of U.S. government bonds fell Wednesday, as optimism about trade negotiations between the White House and Beijing diluted appetite for Treasurys.

title: Dish Loses Subscribers as Disputes With HBO and Univision Continue
summary: Satellite-television provider lost 920,000 net pay-TV subscribers in 2018. Dish Network Corp. reported that it lost subscribers in the latest quarter as pressure from blackouts of HBO and Univision has weighed on its base.

title: HHS to Review Indian Health Service After Revelations on Pedophile Doctor
summary: Agency moved him from one agency-run hospital to another after officials concluded he was molesting children. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar called for a review of the Indian Health Service following an investigation that revealed the agency's mishandling of a pedophile doctor.

title: College Applicants Push Back Against Spies
summary: Colleges need to step back and respect prospective students' privacy.. As a high-school senior who is waiting to hear back from the likes of Columbia, Duke and Yale, I already experience enough good old-fashioned stress. I don't need the high-tech variety, too ("Colleges Track Applicants Online to Size Up Interest," page one, Jan. 28). My peers and I are tired of being subjected to the mysterious whims of these data-hungry institutions, whose invasions have now apparently extended into our quotidian, personal digital activities.

title: Green New Deal Encounters Red Sea of Debt
summary: To replace 850 gigawatts (850,000,000 kilowatts) of installed fossil fuel and nuclear capacity would cost around $425 billion.. Regarding Kimberley Strassel's "The Socialist That Could" (Potomac Watch, Feb. 8): There are two primary concerns I have with the Green New Deal. According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), there was approximately 850 gigawatts of uranium and fossil-fuel installed electricity capacity in the U.S. as of 2016. Also, according to the EIA, as of January 2019, total capital costs per kilowatt for onshore wind range from $1,455 a kilowatt to $2,773 a kilowatt. Solar is $1,759-$3,212 a kilowatt. Let's assume there is amazing innovation and costs decline to $500 a kilowatt for both of them. To replace 850 gigawatts (850,000,000 kilowatts) of capacity would cost $425 billion, give or take a few dozen billion. That's my first concern. My second concern is what happens to my frequent-flier miles if there are no more airplanes?

title: Gov. Cuomo, the SALT Cap And Paying a Fair Share
summary: He can't have it both ways.. Regarding your editorial "Andrew Cuomo's Tears of SALT" (Feb. 12): There's something disingenuous about prominent Democrats claiming, on the one hand, that the Republicans' tax reform mostly benefited "the rich," and, on the other hand, claiming that the cap on state and local tax deductions raised federal taxes on wealthy people in their state. They can't have it both ways. Meanwhile, Republicans should do a better job defending the tax bill which, in fact, lowered federal taxes for most Americans.

title: Praise From Across the Aisle For the Late John Dingell
summary: Today, we need the example of men and women like John Dingell more than ever.. One of the glories of our legislative system is the mutual respect between members, which has characterized much of its history. John Dingell and I followed very different political paths, but never did I doubt his word, his integrity, his honor. Today, we need the example of men and women like John Dingell more than ever ("Obituary: A Longtime Congressman, Master of Gavel," U.S. News, Feb. 8).

title: White House Names Top Executives to Workforce Advisory Board
summary: Leaders of Apple, Home Depot, IBM and Visa are among those chosen for the panel. The Trump administration named prominent business executives to its newly formed workforce-policy advisory board Wednesday, including the leaders of Apple Inc., Home Depot Inc., International Business Machines Corp. and Visa Inc., as well as education and labor officials.

title: New Jersey Dioceses Post Names of Priests Accused of Sexual Abuse
summary: Disclosures come as state attorney general is investigating abuse in church. All of New Jersey's five Catholic Church dioceses on Wednesday released the names of 189 clergy members they said were credibly accused of sexually assaulting minors.

title: Gold Prices Drift Higher After Lukewarm Inflation Data
summary: Gold prices edged up after tepid U.S. inflation data bolstered the case for the Federal Reserve to pause its monetary tightening. Gold prices edged higher Wednesday after tepid U.S. inflation data bolstered the case for the Federal Reserve to pause its monetary tightening.

title: Battle to Oust Islamic State Takes Toll on Syrian Civilians
summary: Refugees face dangerous journey to overcrowded camp as U.S.-backed force fights militants. BEIRUT-Thousands of civilians fleeing the U.S.-backed battle to oust Islamic State from the last territory it controls in Syria have had to run across minefields and ride in open-air trucks for hours in near-freezing temperature to find safety-in a camp with not enough tents.

title: Oil Climbs Despite Rising U.S. Crude Inventories
summary: Investors focused more on a rising U.S. stock market and optimism about U.S.-China trade talks. • Oil prices rose Wednesday as investors shrugged off a report showing U.S. crude-oil inventories are at a 15-month high and focused more on rising U.S. stocks and optimism over U.S.-China trade talks.

title: Annie Leibovitz on Being Envious of Herself
summary: The portrait photographer's earliest work, now on display for the first time in a Hauser & Wirth show, makes her wistful for the old days: "It was just so pure and energetic and out there". After Annie Leibovitz's start as a staff photographer for Jann Wenner's Rolling Stone in 1970, her first cover for the magazine-a black-and-white portrait of a boyish-looking John Lennon-ran in January 1971, when Leibovitz was just 21. Almost a decade later, she took the now-iconic photograph of Lennon nude and curled around Yoko Ono in bed, just hours before Lennon's assassination; the print became the magazine's striking memorial cover. Leibovitz's other subjects for the magazine, where she worked until 1983, when she left for Vanity Fair, included dozens of other artists who shaped the era, like Patti Smith, Bob Dylan and Bob Marley. Now, in Annie Leibovitz: The Early Years, 1970-1983, a new show opening February 14 at Hauser & Wirth in L.A., Leibovitz revisits that work for the first time. The photographer combed through thousands of images to select the more than 4,000 pictures in the exhibition. She talks about curating the show with WSJ.:

title: Suicide Bombing Kills Revolutionary Guards in Iran
summary: Attack targets Iranian military forces in a bus returning from mission along the Pakistan border. TEHRAN-Iran's Revolutionary Guard said a suicide bombing killed 27 of its members and injured another 13 of them in the country's southeast, an area that is home to Sunni insurgents and the site of frequent unrest along the country's border with Pakistan.

title: Mastercard's New CFO to Juggle Growth Efforts Amid Industry Transformation
summary: Sachin Mehra will take the role on April 1, succeeding longtime CFO Martina Hund-Mejean. Mastercard Inc.'s incoming finance chief will help lead the credit-card company's expansion into adjacent businesses as new competition from technology companies continues to transform the payments industry.

title: When Politicians 'Pounce'
summary: Is it time for news editors to retire this cliché?. Media bias may not be as bad as it seems. But that doesn't mean recent coverage of Democrats' "Green New Deal" has been fair or accurate.

title: Strikes at Low-Wage Plants Signal Revival of Labor Demands in Mexico
summary: Workers want higher pay as country prepares to overhaul labor laws. MEXICO CITY-A wave of strikes at low-wage plants in a border city threatens to spark increased labor strife as Mexico prepares to overhaul laws to empower workers following a new trade deal with the U.S. and Canada.

title: Google to Invest $13 Billion in U.S. Data Centers, Offices
summary: Investments would allow the company to create more than 10,000 new construction jobs, CEO says. Google Inc. is planning to spend $13 billion this year on data centers and offices across the U.S., Chief Executive Sundar Pichai said Wednesday.

title: New Barrick Gold CEO Discusses Possibilities for Miner
summary: Mark Bristow says a partnership in Nevada with Newmont could allow the company to share costs. Barrick Gold Corp. favors a partnership with rival Newmont Mining Corp. to combine ore processing operations at some gold mines in Nevada.

title: This Iconic Hollywood Restaurant Lets You Travel Back in Time
summary: The Musso & Frank Grill, one of the first power-lunch spots in Hollywood, turns 100 this year and is remarkably unchanged. Eat there to journey to another world. LONG BEFORE Hollywood Boulevard had its Walk of Fame, it had the Musso & Frank Grill. Or, as it was originally called, "Frank's Café"-the brainchild of entrepreneur Frank Toulet. He opened the joint in 1919, just as Hollywood was completing its metamorphosis from rural backwater to the movie capital of the world. With the nearest eateries still miles away, Toulet figured film workers might appreciate a convenient place to dine.

title: T-Mobile's Sprint Takeover Comes Under New Attack
summary: Wireless executives face criticism at House hearing about impact of proposed tie-up on competition and jobs. WASHINGTON-The leaders of the country's No. 3 and No. 4 largest cellphone carriers defended their planned merger against new attacks from labor groups and advocates for rural wireless customers who said the tie-up would hurt consumers.

title: The Musso & Frank Grill At 100
summary: Still serving one of the best martinis in town. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Venture Investors to Score Giant Win From $3.4 Billion Sale of Auris Health
summary: Johnson & Johnson's deal for medical-robotics startup is largest on record for a venture-backed medical-device company.. Johnson & Johnson's $3.4 billion cash deal to buy Auris Health Inc. is the largest acquisition on record for a venture-backed medical-device company and a victory for investors in the startup led by medical-robotics entrepreneur Fred Moll.

title: Energy Prices Hold Down Overall U.S. Inflation
summary: Consumer prices were flat in January for the third month in a row, but underlying price growth remains steady. WASHINGTON-Volatile energy prices are holding down overall inflation in the U.S. economy, but underlying price growth remains steady.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Buy Surgical Robotics Maker Auris
summary: Auris's technology will help J&J make a digital solution catered to different parts of patients' lung-cancer treatment. Johnson & Johnson 's Ethicon unit has reached a deal to buy medical technology firm Auris Health Inc. for about $3.4 billion in cash, expanding J&J's push into the use of robotic technology for medical procedures and surgery.

title: How to Host a Dinner Like a Pro
summary: At a new culinary school with an emphasis on hospitality, you can learn how to roll out a proper New Orleans welcome. TEACHING hospitality is more than teaching service. It's more than " 'Put the fork like this,' " said Ti Adelaide Martin. As a proprietor of the venerable Commander's Palace restaurant and scion of a New Orleans restaurant dynasty, Ms. Martin knows what it takes to make guests feel welcome-and she's ready to pass that knowledge on.

title: Ecuador, IMF Launch Formal Talks on Possible Bailout Package
summary: South American country needs funds to cover a budget deficit and pay debt holders. The International Monetary Fund and the government of Ecuador have launched formal talks about a potential financial bailout for the South American country, which needs funds to cover a budget deficit and pay debt holders.

title: California Coast Ranch Linked to Formula One Heavyweight Lists for $110 Million
summary: Near Santa Barbara, it is one of the priciest properties ever listed in the area.. A 3,500-acre California coast ranch linked to Mansour Ojjeh, a French-Saudi Arabian entrepreneur whose company is a major shareholder in British-based car maker McLaren and its Formula One racing team, is listing for $110 million.

title: IPG Says Its Consumer-Goods Business Is Doing Fine
summary: Rival ad giant Publicis Groupe recently warned of consumer-goods pullbacks. Interpublic Group of Cos. on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter growth across a number of client categories, including health care and consumer goods, despite the many challenges facing the ad business, from client cutbacks to political turmoil around the world.

title: Why Amazon Just Raised Your Grocery Bill
summary: Prices are going up for Whole Foods shoppers, Prime members or not. Whole Paycheck is back.

title: Pentagon Chief Tries to Reassure NATO Allies
summary: President Trump has berated U.S. allies for not contributing enough to funding the military alliance. BRUSSELS-Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan sought to reassure fellow NATO members about the U.S. commitment to an alliance unsettled by President Trump's mixed messages and the breakdown of a Cold War-era nuclear treaty.

title: Fed's Harker Sees One Rate Increase in 2019, One in 2020
summary: 'I continue to be in wait-and-see mode,' Philadelphia Fed president says, citing uncertainty about the economy. Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker said Wednesday the Fed should raise rates once this year and once next year.

title: The Hot Trade in the Housing Market: Servicing Your Mortgage
summary: The cooling housing market and higher interest rates are slowing mortgage originations, fueling sales of servicing rights. The mortgage-market slowdown is stirring up interest in a humdrum segment of American home lending: the rights to the arcane task of handling monthly payments.

title: Carlos Ghosn Replaces Lawyers, Hires 'the Razor' to Lead Defense
summary: Veteran lawyer Junichiro Hironaka has won some of Japan's most famous acquittals. Former Nissan Motor Co. Chairman Carlos Ghosn, facing trial in Japan on financial charges, replaced his legal team and brought in a lawyer noted for high-profile cases to lead his defense.

title: Is It Healthy to Study in Bed?
summary: Experts weigh in on a topic parents and their school-age children often clash over; their views on the pros and cons of bed-studying may surprise you. With extracurriculars, academics and a social life to maintain, goal-oriented students have to squeeze time from their hectic schedules to get homework done. The result? Lots of studying, writing and reading happens while lying or lounging in bed. Though many parents insist children study only at a desk, they may be surprised to hear what experts think about where and when it's best to review and learn. We gathered informed opinions from experts in education psychology, sleep medicine and ergonomics.

title: CUNY Names Félix Matos Rodríguez as Chancellor
summary: Matos Rodríguez will be first Latino leader for New York City's public higher education system. Queens College President Félix Matos Rodríguez is set to become the next chancellor of the City University of New York, ending a yearlong search for a leader of one of the nation's biggest public higher-education systems.

title: Osram Licht Confirms Takeover Talks With Bain Capital, Carlyle Group
summary: Resume Subscription. Osram Licht AG has confirmed that it is in talks with private-equity investors Bain Capital and Carlyle Group , backing earlier reports of a joint takeover bid for the Munich-based lighting company drove its shares higher earlier today.

title: 'Stuff' Really Is Getting More Expensive
summary: Aside from energy, the price of goods is creeping higher for the first time in over five years. Americans have been paying more for stuff lately. That actually counts as something new.

title: Teva's Turnaround Stalls Out
summary: Weak 2019 profit outlook means Wall Street is likely too optimistic. Those betting on a turnaround at Teva Pharmaceutical Industries will need a fresh dose of patience.

title: A Political Turning Point for 'Inflection'
summary: Once the term meant a bending line in a graph, then a business breakthrough-and now a pivotal moment for the country. When California Sen. Kamala Harris kicked off her campaign for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination with a rally in Oakland last month, she told the crowd, "We are at an inflection point in the history of our nation." In a tweet before the current president's recent State of the Union address, she invoked the same idea but called it an "inflection moment."

title: Can a Grown Woman Wear a Hair Bow?
summary: Although designers and celebrities are currently loopy over bows, women are split on whether the look is more Catherine Deneuve or Minnie Mouse. DURING MY CHILDHOOD in the Chicago suburbs, every day was a hair-bow day. Piano recitals and church on Sundays were cause for embellishment, sure, but so were apple picking and playing soccer. So my heart skipped a beat when, decades later, in my capacity as a fashion reporter, I watched the hair adornment come down the spring 2016 Oscar de la Renta runway in its simplest form-black and loosely tied. Since then, hair bows, once the territory of girlish characters like Hello Kitty, have become a signature for fashionable women like Ariana Grande and Kate Middleton. I have eagerly tried them in many forms, feeling festive on Christmas Eve with a bejeweled barrette and fancying myself the most put-together mom at preschool pickup with a simple grosgrain strand tying back my waves.

title: It's February, Why Are There Bare Ankles Everywhere?
summary: Resume Subscription. Chelsea Eyre bundled up on a recent frigid day in a hooded alpaca and wool coat with a down liner, boots, a scarf and gloves.

title: A Belgian Castle With a Heroic Past
summary: Built in the 1630s, Château de Haltinne was a hideout for a Jewish couple evading the Nazis. The roughly 33,000-square-foot property is now listed for $15.3 million.. Château de Haltinne, a moated castle in the heart of Belgium, dates to the 1630s, but left its mark in the 20th century with acts of heroism in World War II.

summary: Fischer will join the asset manager as a senior adviser. Former Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer will join BlackRock Inc. as a senior adviser, the asset manager said Wednesday.

title: Small Companies Face Added Pressure to Put Women on Boards
summary: Proxy adviser Glass Lewis will advise investors to vote against a key committee chair on all-male boards in the Russell 3000 Index. The number of large public companies with all-male boards has dwindled in recent years as investors have demanded more boardroom diversity. Now the pressure is trickling down to smaller companies.

title: After Escaping London's Blitz as a Child, Michael Caine Is Still Hiding Out in the Country
summary: The Oscar-winning actor grew up in one of the poorest sections of London, fleeing the city in World War II. Today, he finds peace in the gardens of a home in Surrey.. Michael Caine, 85, is a two-time Oscar-winning actor who starred in films including "Alfie," "Educating Rita," "The Cider House Rules" and "Hannah and Her Sisters." He is author of the memoir "Blowing the Bloody Doors Off" (Hachette). He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: New York City Council Members Want to Dial Down Sirens
summary: Noise pollution is a major health concern, says Democrat who helped draft the bill. summary: U.S. carriers' success with more tailored customer offers may not be repeated in a recession. U.S. airlines are testing a new secret weapon: passenger segmentation. So far it seems to hit the mark, but executives likely overrate its firepower during bad times.

title: GE Power Has a $92 Billion Backlog. For the New Boss, That's a Problem.
summary: CEO Larry Culp says turbine-making division is weighed down by low-margin orders that came from chasing market share. The turnaround of General Electric Co. depends on the revival of its core power business, a reversal that will require Chief Executive Larry Culp to churn through a $92 billion sales backlog marred by lousy projects.

title: Just How Green Are U.S. Airlines?
summary: Carriers want fliers to see them as eco-friendly-but while their planes are more efficient, their greenhouse-gas emissions are rising overall. Virgin Atlantic Airways flew the first biofuel demonstration flight in 2008. Eleven years later, no airline has done much more than that. One of the major elements in reducing aviation-produced greenhouse gases has yet to take off.

title: The Rules of Comedy in Iraq
summary: Former 'Seinfeld' writer Larry Charles explores the quest for laughs in some of the world's most dangerous places for his Netflix series. If anyone was going to explore the world's most life-threatening war zones and bastions of unfree speech-through comedy-Larry Charles was the guy.

title: Stocks to Watch: Activision Blizzard, TripAdvisor, Twilio, Lattice Semiconductor, Akamai Technologies
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Italy's Far-Right Firebrand Takes Aim at Europe
summary: Matteo Salvini's profile has skyrocketed on radical rhetoric and an everyman image, but his decisions reflect a more pragmatic politician. PIANELLA, Italy-Far-right lnterior Minister Matteo Salvini strolled through a crowd of supporters in the main square of this southern Abruzzo town. Leaping on stage to campaign for regional elections, Mr. Salvini took aim at prosecutors who have charged him with kidnapping 177 African migrants last year after he refused to let them disembark from a rescue ship.

title: In New York City, Restaurants Welcome Tables for One
summary: With solo dining on the rise, some restaurants see party-of-one guests as ideal. In New York City restaurants, the party-of-one is becoming a cause for celebration.

title: In Washington, Sheriffs Refuse to Enforce New Gun Laws
summary: Attorney general issues warning as rural officials oppose measure passed by voters. More than a dozen county sheriffs in Washington state are refusing to enforce a sweeping gun-control measure that passed with the support of 59% of the state's voters in November.

title: What Fleabag's Vicky Jones Has on Her Phone
summary: The writer and director shares what's on her phone. Number of unread emails: This is embarrassing: 4,465. I got into this terrible habit years ago of leaving things unread to remind me to deal with them.

title: The Standard's New Food Guru on Overhauling the Hotel's Cuisine
summary: Meet Angela Dimayuga, who's redefining the hotel's culinary program-including its first overseas property. Since Angela Dimayuga became creative director of food and culture at Standard International in April, she has made collaboration a key factor in refreshing the hotel brand's existing culinary offerings as well as its projects in development. Dimayuga, 33, ran the kitchen at Mission Chinese Food's Manhattan location for six years and says her new role at Standard International-ranging from conceptualizing fundraising dinners to choosing DJs for an upcoming bar opening-speaks to how she needed to broaden her own mission as a chef. "I wanted to do something nobody expected of me," she says, "and that I didn't expect of myself." Among her first changes have been installing chef Max Blachman-Gentile at Narcissa in The Standard East Village, where his bread program is already drawing attention. She's also readying three new dining concepts at The Standard London, the brand's first-ever international property, slated to open this spring. Its pub, Double Standard, will mesh British and American sensibilities. A garden restaurant called Isla, helmed by Adam Rawson, will feature coastal-inspired cuisine. And a 10th-floor space will offer the open-fire cuisine of Michelin-starred chef Peter Sanchez-Iglesias. "People ask me if I miss cooking every night," says Dimayuga. "I'm designing dishes now with people I admire. I don't want it to be the Angela show. That would be really boring for me."

title: Philippine Editor Critical of Duterte Government Is Arrested for Libel
summary: Human rights groups say move is an attempt to muzzle president's political opponents. The editor of a news site that has been critical of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte was arrested for libel, extending a crackdown on critics that rights groups say is aimed at muzzling his political opponents.

title: King of Generics Pushes Into Biotech Drugs
summary: New Teva CEO seeks to revive company's fortunes with focus on pricier, biologic medicines. The world's largest maker of generic drugs is looking for growth in an unlikely place: high-price biotech medicines.

title: Beer Is Unlikely Winner From Teetotal Trend
summary: Heineken's strong 2018 sales were helped by its no-alcohol offerings. Global brewers are unlikely winners from the trend toward temperance. That is bad news for soda companies like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo .

title: NHL's Comeback: Loads of Goals and Surprises
summary: More players with advanced scoring skills and rules favoring offense have resulted in a scoring bonanza this season. Early in the NHL season, the Calgary Flames trailed the Colorado Avalanche 4-1 to start the third period-the kind of dreary home game that provokes fans to leave early. But these days, there are more reasons to stay.

title: Bank Mergers Get Faster Under Trump
summary: Regulators' friendlier approach could result in more deals, but some Democrats worry the transactions aren't getting enough scrutiny. WASHINGTON-Bank mergers are getting speedier under President Trump, with federal regulators changing policies that had deterred deals after the financial crisis.

title: Chicago Cubs, Sinclair Create New Cable Channel for Games
summary: The new Marquee Sports Network will be the first regional sports channel for Sinclair, which owns and operates 191 local TV stations. The Chicago Cubs and Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. are forming a regional sports network that will carry the team's games starting in 2020.

title: Consumer Companies Prove Resilient in China Despite Slowdown
summary: Japanese corporate results suggest that trade tensions, while a blow to some tech companies, have left other industries relatively unscathed. TOKYO-China's factories are trimming investment, but consumers are still spending more on some luxury and everyday items.

title: Trump's Border-Deal Ambivalence Adds to Shutdown Suspense
summary: President doesn't rule out signing compromise legislation to avoid government shutdown. WASHINGTON-President Trump sent mixed signals on a bipartisan border-security deal reached by lawmakers, but he didn't rule out ultimately signing the resulting legislation, injecting new suspense over whether another government shutdown would begin this weekend.

title: The Unrealistic Economics of the Green New Deal
summary: Saving planet, creating jobs are noble ideas-but by combining them, Democratic plan exacts too high a cost. The Green New Deal that some Democrats unveiled last week is actually two deals: one to combat global warming, another to create millions of well-paid jobs for targeted groups.

title: Self-Driving Truck Tech Startup TuSimple Raises $95 Million in New Funding
summary: Company says backing will support expansion of autonomous fleet, work with truck manufacturers. Autonomous trucking firm TuSimple has raised $95 million to expand its fleet of self-driving big rigs and fund joint product development with truck manufacturers and equipment makers, the company said Wednesday.

title: New Nafta Is Threatened by Partisan Split Over Enforcement
summary: Democrats, White House are clashing over enforcement of provisions on the environment, workers' right to form unions. WASHINGTON-A sharp divide between Democrats and the Trump administration over how to enforce trade rules is threatening to delay or derail a congressional vote on a new version of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Thai Party That Pushed Princess for Prime Minister Is Threatened With Dissolution
summary: Shutting down Thai Raksa Chart Party would strengthen ruling junta's hand as pivotal election nears. Thailand's election authorities are seeking to disband a leading opposition party for nominating a princess as its candidate for prime minister-strengthening the ruling junta's hand as next month's pivotal national election approaches.

title: Lampert's Plan for Sears: Smaller Stores, Less Apparel
summary: Hedge-fund manager wants to shrink remaining Sears and Kmart stores and sell less apparel; hiring a new CEO. Edward Lampert has a plan for Sears after its trip through bankruptcy: smaller stores and less apparel.

title: Cisco Growth Could Feel Pressure From Tariffs
summary: What to watch as the networking-hardware company reports its results. Cisco Systems Inc. is scheduled to report its fiscal second-quarter results after the market closes Wednesday. Here's what you need to know:

title: China Has Caught the CFA Fever
summary: Resume Subscription. Tales of China's growing influence are often illustrated with evidence such as its staggeringly high number of science graduates or patent applications. Here's another data point with more immediate relevance for the investment industry: More than 30% of people who take the Chartered Financial Analyst exams each year now take them in mainland China, according to the CFA Institute.

title: The Myths and Legends of Japan's 20 Years With Zero Interest Rates
summary: Japan's two decades of zero interest rates just haven't stimulated enough. A time traveler from 1999 would find some familiar comforts in 2019: overalls have made a comeback, Pokémon is wildly popular and interest rates in Japan are still stuck around zero.

title: Australia's Strict Stance on Asylum Seekers Starts to Crack
summary: New legislation allows those held in detention centers to be brought to Australia for medical treatment. CANBERRA-Australia's parliament narrowly approved legislation to allow asylum seekers held in detention centers on Pacific islands to be brought to the country for medical treatment, an easing of its strict policy toward migrants arriving by boat and a setback for the conservative government, which had opposed the move.

title: How to Host a Dinner Like a Pro
summary: At a new culinary school with an emphasis on hospitality, you can learn how to roll out a proper New Orleans welcome. TEACHING hospitality is more than teaching service. It's more than " 'Put the fork like this,' " said Ti Adelaide Martin. As a proprietor of the venerable Commander's Palace restaurant and scion of a New Orleans restaurant dynasty, Ms. Martin knows what it takes to make guests feel welcome-and she's ready to pass that knowledge on.

title: NYPD Detective Killed by Friendly Fire
summary: He and a wounded officer were responding to an armed robbery; suspect was shot and arrested. A New York Police Department detective was fatally shot by friendly fire while responding to an armed robbery in Queens on Tuesday afternoon, NYPD Commissioner James O'Neill said.

title: What El Chapo's Trial Revealed: The Inner Workings of a $14 Billion Drug Empire
summary: Trial testimony laid bare the organization's technological prowess, leadership structure and innovative use of chile pepper cans. The trial of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, and his conviction Tuesday on drug-smuggling charges, brought to an end the decadeslong career of the notorious "El Chapo." It also revealed in remarkable detail the inner workings of the criminal empire he built, one that rivaled governments and multinational companies in its power and sophistication.

title: Maduro's Foreign Minister Courts Support, Mediation From U.N.
summary: U.S. is seeking international recognition of Venezuelan opposition leader Guaidó. UNITED NATIONS-The foreign minister for the Venezuelan government of Nicolás Maduro said on Tuesday that his government is ready to negotiate with the opposition and that the country plans to increase its cooperation with U.N. agencies to improve the economy.

title: BuzzFeed News Employees Vote to Unionize
summary: Decision to unionize follows similar moves at Vice News, Vox Media and other digital upstarts. Employees at BuzzFeed News have voted to unionize, weeks after executives at the digital-media company announced substantial layoffs to steer the startup to profitability.

title: RBNZ Keeps Rates Steady; Holds Course on Balanced Outlook
summary: The central bank warned that growth among New Zealand's major trading partners is expected to slow. SYDNEY-The Reserve Bank of New Zealand on Wednesday left interest rates unchanged, retaining a fairly balanced outlook, while warning that a sharper global downturn could weigh on the economy.

title: White House Calls on Trump Supporters to Behave Peacefully
summary: The BBC says its cameraman 'was violently pushed and shoved' at a rally Monday in El Paso, Texas. The White House called on people attending President Trump's campaign rallies to behave peacefully, following an incident Monday in which a Trump supporter allegedly assaulted a TV cameraman working in an area reserved for the news media.

title: China, U.S. Seek Broad Outline of a Trade Pact This Week
summary: Differences are still substantial between what Beijing is willing to offer and what U.S. will accept. U.S. stocks rose Tuesday as President Trump said he is willing to delay next month's deadline for resolving the U.S.'s trade conflict with China if negotiations with Beijing are progressing smoothly.

title: América Móvil Swings to Profit in Fourth Quarter
summary: Mobile phone operator ended last year with 275.8 million mobile subscribers. MEXICO CITY-Latin American mobile phone operator América Móvil SAB swung to a net profit in the fourth quarter thanks to higher operating gains and lower financial costs.

title: Suit Accuses Current, Former CBS Executives of Insider Trading
summary: Moonves, Ianniello sold millions of dollars in CBS shares before misconduct allegations became public, complaint says. Several current and former CBS Corp. executives engaged in insider trading in advance of sexual-harassment allegations against former Chairman and Chief Executive Leslie Moonves becoming public, according to a shareholder lawsuit seeking class-action status against the company.

title: FDA Panel to Assess Risks of Women's Surgical Mesh
summary: Doctors recommend that the agency evaluate women's self-reports as it decides whether the product should stay on the market. WASHINGTON-Officials should consider women's reports of pain, sexual dysfunction and other maladies as they re-evaluate a medical device used in women's pelvic surgery that has triggered thousands of lawsuits, an advisory panel said.

title: Declaring Border Victory
summary: The bipartisan deal is his only good way out of this budget box canyon.. Congressional negotiators have reached a funding deal on border security, and President Trump said Tuesday he's "not happy" with it. He could refuse to sign it and endure the political damage from another government shutdown. But he'd do better by himself, his party and the country by following the advice that Senator George Aiken famously offered during the Vietnam War: Declare victory and get out.

title: Didn't We Already Beat Measles?
summary: Fifty-three cases are now confirmed, most in unvaccinated kids.. Many conservatives are fond of an old T.S. Eliot line: There is no such thing as a Lost Cause because there is no such thing as a Gained Cause. The latest proof of that second truth is the Pacific Northwest's outbreak of measles, a disease scrubbed from the U.S. nearly 20 years ago.

title: Jobs and Steel Tariffs
summary: Border taxes produce small benefits for some, higher costs for many.. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is upset that we're not converts to the Trump tariff campaign, as he makes clear in a nearby letter. Fair enough, but since he brings up our use of data, another word is in order.

title: Fashion Mogul Tommy Hilfiger Sells Miami Beach Hotel He Aimed to Restore
summary: A company controlled by Mr. Hilfiger and its partner, Dogus Group, are selling the historic Raleigh Hotel on Collins Avenue for $103 million. Fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger is checking out early from his investment in a Miami Beach, Fla., hotel.
